0.text: For people with a moderate form of OCD, intrusive thoughts and compulsions can take 1–3 hours a day, while in more severe cases these thoughts and rituals can occupy more than 8 hours a day.
0.fact: Research shows that more than 60% of people with OCD experience intrusive thoughts on a daily basis.

1.text: Around 50% of people with OCD report that their intrusive thoughts and compulsions significantly interfere with everyday life, including work, study and social interactions.
1.fact: Frequent and prolonged intrusive thoughts can lead to physical exhaustion and health problems such as headaches, digestive issues and chronic fatigue.

2.text: Intense distress caused by intrusive thoughts can show up as physical symptoms, such as headaches, muscle tension and digestive problems.
2.fact: Although Franklin Delano Roosevelt never received an official OCD diagnosis, historians note that his obsessive thoughts caused him considerable distress and influenced his mood and daily life.

3.text: The intensity and frequency of intrusive thoughts can vary greatly from person to person. Some are able to cope with them most of the time, while others experience ongoing difficulty.
3.fact: CBT, especially exposure and response prevention (ERP), is one of the most effective treatments for OCD and helps people learn to resist intrusive thoughts.

4.text: Only about 10–20% of people with OCD report that they are mostly able to control their intrusive thoughts.
4.fact: Antidepressants such as SSRIs often help people with OCD reduce the intensity of intrusive thoughts and improve their ability to manage them.

5.text: The most common compulsive actions include frequent handwashing, repeatedly checking locks and household appliances, and repeated behaviours such as touching certain objects or repeating specific words or phrases.
5.fact: Fewer than 5% of people with OCD perform compulsive actions for more than 8 hours a day, but when this happens it severely disrupts daily life.

6.text: Compulsive actions can interfere with work or study by lowering productivity and making it hard to complete tasks. Some people have to cut back their working hours or even change jobs because of their symptoms.
6.fact: The compulsive actions of Howard Hughes, such as constant handwashing and avoiding contact with others, led to his social isolation and major changes in his life. Eventually, his OCD had a serious impact on both his health and his career.

7.text: Compulsive actions are often accompanied by strong negative emotions such as anxiety, guilt, shame and frustration. These feelings can significantly increase overall distress and a sense of being overwhelmed.
7.fact: People with OCD often live with additional conditions such as depression and anxiety disorders, which makes their experience heavier and intensifies feelings of discomfort.

8.text: Levels of stress and anxiety play a major role in the ability to resist rituals. In periods of heightened stress it becomes much harder to resist compulsive behaviours.
8.fact: Footballer David Beckham has spoken about his OCD and says that sometimes he manages to resist performing rituals, especially with support from his family and therapists.

9.text: Roughly 30–35% of people report that they can control their rituals most of the time.
9.fact: Mindfulness and meditation practices can help improve control over rituals by reducing anxiety and supporting overall mental health.

normal.text: Your results do not indicate pronounced signs of obsessive-compulsive disorder. Even if intrusive thoughts or urges do appear from time to time, they do not cause noticeable discomfort or interfere with your daily life. Overall, you are able to stay in control of your thoughts and behaviour and feel emotionally stable.
normal.title: Normal state

light.text: From time to time you may notice recurring thoughts or an urge to double-check something, especially in stressful situations. These experiences are not constant and usually do not disrupt your usual rhythm of life. You are generally able to keep these impulses under control and manage day-to-day tasks. If some thoughts or actions start to make you feel more anxious, gentle self-regulation techniques can help you maintain emotional balance.
light.title: Mild OCD symptoms

severe.text: You may face persistent thoughts or rituals that help you reduce anxiety but sometimes limit your freedom of action or take up noticeable time. The need for order, control or specific rituals can create tension, especially when circumstances prevent you from following your usual rules. At times you are able to cope with this on your own, but occasional support from a specialist may be helpful to reduce the strain and increase your flexibility.
severe.title: Moderate OCD symptoms

extreme.text: Your answers suggest that intrusive thoughts and rituals may significantly affect your daily life and emotional state. You might feel strong anxiety if you cannot carry out familiar actions, and this can be a major source of stress. In such cases, reaching out for professional help can be an important step towards feeling better and reducing tension. Support is available, and you do not have to go through this alone.
extreme.title: Pronounced OCD symptoms

text: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is linked to intrusive thoughts and repetitive actions that a person performs to reduce anxiety.
OCD can show up in many ways: from occasional intrusive thoughts to repeated actions and mental rituals that take time and attention.
This condition is relatively common, and an important step is to treat your experiences with care and seek support when needed — this helps maintain quality of life and emotional wellbeing.
